Each row denotes a different coalition partition: for example, {a,b}â€‹{c}ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\{a,b\}\{c\} indicates that players ağ‘a and bğ‘b are federating together while cğ‘c is alone.

references: First, we will analyze uniform federation, with three players, a,b,ğ‘ğ‘a,b, and cğ‘c. We will first assume that each player has 5 samples from their local data distribution: Table 1 gives the error each player can expect in this situation. Arrangements equivalent up to renaming of players are omitted. Every player sees its error minimized in the â€œgrand coalitionâ€ Ï€gsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘”\pi_{g} where all three players are federating together. This implies that the only arrangement that is stable (core-stable or individually stable) is Ï€gsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘”\pi_{g}.

Thirdly, we will assume that all three players have 25 samples: this example is shown in Table 3. As in Table 1, the players have identical preferences. However, in this case, the players minimize their error by being alone. Overall, stability results from this example are part of a broader pattern we will analyze in later sections.

references: Next, we assume that player cğ‘c increases the amount of samples it has from 5 to 25: Table 2 demonstrates the error each player can expect in this situation. Here, the players have different preferences over which arrangement they would most prefer. The â€œsmallâ€ players ağ‘a and bğ‘b would most prefer {a,b}â€‹{c}ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\{a,b\}\{c\}, whereas the â€œlargeâ€ player cğ‘c would most prefer {a},{b,c}ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\{a\},\{b,c\} or (identically) {b},{a,c}ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\{b\},\{a,c\}. However out of all of these coalition structures, only {a,b},{c}ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\{a,b\},\{c\} is stable (either core stable or individually stable). Note that {a},{b,c}ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\{a\},\{b,c\} is not stable because the coalition C={a,b}ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘C=\{a,b\} is one where each player prefers Cğ¶C to its current situation.

references: Table 4 shows an example using coarse federation with four players: three have 30 samples each, and the fourth player has 300 samples. We assume the weights wjsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—w_{j} are set optimally for each player. For conciseness, some columns and rows are omitted. Note that both player types get lower error in Ï€gsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘”\pi_{g} than they would with local learning: that is, Ï€gsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘”\pi_{g} is individually stable (stable against defections of any player alone). However, it is also clear that Ï€gsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘”\pi_{g} is not core stable: in particular, the three small players would get lower error in {a,b,c}ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\{a,b,c\} than in Ï€gsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘”\pi_{g}. These results will be examined theoretically in later sections: with optimal weighting, coarse-grained federation will always have an individually stable Ï€gsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘”\pi_{g} that is not necessarily core stable.

references: Finally, we examine fine-grained federation. Table 5 analyzes the same case as coarse-grained federation previously, but with optimally-weighted fine-grained federation. The full error table shows that Ï€gsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘”\pi_{g} is core stable because each player minimizes their error in this arrangement. This result will hold theoretically: when optimal fine-grained federation is used, Ï€gsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘”\pi_{g} always minimizes error for every player and is thus core stable.
